analyzed: zhes bya ba yin no zhes bstan to //
translated: The context is this:üîΩThe context is this

original: 'di la drang srong chen po 'jig rten mig ces bya ba des grangs can dag kho na'i gyes pa gcig la brten nas 'jig rten rgyang pan pa'i grub pa'i mtha' 'bum byas pas de 'di skad ces /
analyzed: 'di la drang srong chen po 'jig rten mig ces bya ba des grangs can dag kho na'i gyes pa gcig la brten nas 'jig rten rgyang pan pa'i grub pa'i mtha' 'bum byas pas de 'di skad ces /
translated: The great sage LokƒÅk·π£in, relying on a single schism of the SƒÅ·πÉkhya, composed the LokƒÅyata treatise called the Hundred Thousand.

original: sems can skye ba gzhan du las dge ba dang mi dge ba nye bar bsags pa'i rgyu can dag 'dir skye bar 'gyur ba yang med do //
analyzed: sems can skye ba gzhan du las dge ba dang mi dge ba nye bar bsags pa'i rgyu can dag 'dir skye bar 'gyur ba yang med do //
translated: He said, ‚ÄúThere is no sentient being who is born here due to the cause of accumulating virtuous and nonvirtuous karma in another life.

original: 'das pa'i 'jig rten yang med do //
analyzed: 'das pa'i 'jig rten yang med do //
translated: There is no past world.

original: de nas 'dir 'ong ba yang 'ga' yang med do //
analyzed: de nas 'dir 'ong ba yang 'ga' yang med do //
translated: There is no one who comes here from there.

original: 'di nas gang du 'gro bar 'gyur ba'i 'jig rten gzhan yang med de /
analyzed: 'di nas gang du 'gro bar 'gyur ba'i 'jig rten gzhan yang med de /
translated: There is no other world to which one goes from here.

original: 'di ltar rgyu las dang nyon mongs pa med par yang bu ram dang / chu dang / skyu ru ra dang / dha ta ki dang / phabs dang / 'bras phye dang / shing shun la sogs pa sman bsdus te mnan pa las bu ram chang gi khyad par rnam pa tha dad pa ro dang mthu dang smin pa tha dad pa dag 'byung bar 'gyur ba de dag kyang 'jig rten pha rol nas 'ongs te 'dir skye ba ma yin
analyzed: 'di ltar rgyu las dang nyon mongs pa med par yang bu ram dang / chu dang / skyu ru ra dang / dha ta ki dang / phabs dang / 'bras phye dang / shing shun la sogs pa sman bsdus te mnan pa las bu ram chang gi khyad par rnam pa tha dad pa ro dang mthu dang smin pa tha dad pa dag 'byung bar 'gyur ba de dag kyang 'jig rten pha rol nas 'ongs te 'dir skye ba ma yin
translated: In the same way, without the causes of karma and affliction, from the combination of sugar, water, tamarind, dhataki, yeast, rice flour, tree bark, and so on, and through the power of pressing, different types of sugar wine with different tastes, potencies, and effects arise.üîΩThey do not arise from another world and come here to be born.

original: gyi / 'di ltar bu ram dang / chu dang / skyu ru ra dang / dha ta ki dang / phabs dang / 'bras phye dang / shing shun la sogs pa sman gyi rdzas de dag nyid bsdus te mnan pa'i mthu las bu ram chang de lta bur 'gyur ba yin no //
analyzed: gyi / 'di ltar bu ram dang / chu dang / skyu ru ra dang / dha ta ki dang / phabs dang / 'bras phye dang / shing shun la sogs pa sman gyi rdzas de dag nyid bsdus te mnan pa'i mthu las bu ram chang de lta bur 'gyur ba yin no //
translated: Rather, it is through the power of combining and pressing those substances such as sugar, water, tamarind, dhataki, yeast, rice flour, tree bark, and so on that such sugar wine comes to be.

original: de bzhin du nang gi skye mched rnams kyang las dang nyon mongs pa dag med par khu chu dang / khrag la sogs pa tshogs pa las skye'o //
analyzed: de bzhin du nang gi skye mched rnams kyang las dang nyon mongs pa dag med par khu chu dang / khrag la sogs pa tshogs pa las skye'o //
translated: Likewise, the internal sense spheres arise from the assembly of semen, blood, and so on, without karma and afflictions.

original: gzhan yang gal te sha'i phung po ri rab tsam spungs te /
analyzed: gzhan yang gal te sha'i phung po ri rab tsam spungs te /
translated: Moreover, if a heap of flesh the size of Mount Meru were to be piled up,

original: der zhag bdun gyi bar du char bab par 'gyur na /
analyzed: der zhag bdun gyi bar du char bab par 'gyur na /
translated: and if rain were to fall on it for seven days,

original: der sha'i phung po'i tshad kho na tsam gyi srin bu'i phung po skye bar 'gyur na /
analyzed: der sha'i phung po'i tshad kho na tsam gyi srin bu'i phung po skye bar 'gyur na /
translated: a heap of worms would arise from that heap of flesh, the size of the heap of flesh itself.

original: ci de snyed kyi sems can de dag 'jig rten pha rol nas 'ongs sam zhes zer te /
analyzed: ci de snyed kyi sems can de dag 'jig rten pha rol nas 'ongs sam zhes zer te /
translated: Do those sentient beings come from another world?

original: de dag la sogs pa dpe ltar snang ba du ma dag gis rgyu med pa las skye bar sems pas de dag la sogs pa lta ba ngan pa spang ba'i phyir /
analyzed: de dag la sogs pa dpe ltar snang ba du ma dag gis rgyu med pa las skye bar sems pas de dag la sogs pa lta ba ngan pa spang ba'i phyir /
translated: In order to abandon such bad views,

original: slob dpon klu sgrub @112b kyi zhal snga nas kyis rgyu med pa las /üîΩdngos po gang dag gang na yang //
analyzed: slob dpon klu sgrub @112b kyi zhal snga nas kyis rgyu med pa las / dngos po gang dag gang na yang //
translated: the master NƒÅgƒÅrjuna said:üîΩThings that arise from no cause

original: skyes pa nam yang yod ma yin //üîΩzhes bya ba 'di bka' stsal to //
analyzed: skyes pa nam yang yod ma yin //üîΩzhes bya ba 'di bka' stsal to //
translated: have never existed anywhere.

original: ci'i phyir zhe na zhes bya ba ni 'grel ba byed pa nyid kyis /
analyzed: ci'i phyir zhe na zhes bya ba ni 'grel ba byed pa nyid kyis /
translated: The Subcommentary states:

original: gal te gzhan dag ci'i phyir rgyu med pa las skye ba med snyam du sems pa'i bsam pa la brtags nas dogs pa bsu ba'i tshul du dri ba yin no //
analyzed: gal te gzhan dag ci'i phyir rgyu med pa las skye ba med snyam du sems pa'i bsam pa la brtags nas dogs pa bsu ba'i tshul du dri ba yin no //
translated: If others think, ‚ÄúWhy do things not arise causelessly?‚Äù the question is asked in the manner of anticipating their qualm, examining their thought.

original: de'i phyir de ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / rjes su dpag pa dang grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir yang ngo zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba smras so //
analyzed: de'i phyir de ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / rjes su dpag pa dang grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir yang ngo zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba smras so //
translated: Therefore, it is thought that the error of the nonexistence of an inference that teaches that and the error of the refutation by inference and renown exist.

original: 'di skad bstan te /
analyzed: 'di skad bstan te /
translated: This is taught.

original: khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa'i don de ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir /
analyzed: khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa'i don de ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir /
translated: Because there is no inference that teaches the meaning of your proof that things arise causelessly,

original: 'di ltar de ni tshig tsam du zad pas de'i phyir dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med do //
analyzed: 'di ltar de ni tshig tsam du zad pas de'i phyir dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med do //
translated: since it is mere words, therefore things do not arise causelessly.

original: gzhan yang khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa de la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir dang / grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med do //
analyzed: gzhan yang khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa de la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir dang / grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med do //
translated: Moreover, because of the fault of being undermined by inference and because of the fault of being undermined by what is commonly acknowledged, things do not arise without a cause.üîΩThe phrase ‚Äúand so on‚Äù means that the fault of both is included.

original: yang ngo zhes bya ba'i sgras ni skyon gnyi ga bsdu ba'i don to zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba ni de ltar khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa'i don de ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / khyod kyi phyogs 'di la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon dang /üîΩgrags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir /
analyzed: yang ngo zhes bya ba'i sgras ni skyon gnyi ga bsdu ba'i don to zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba ni de ltar khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa'i don de ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / khyod kyi phyogs 'di la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon dang / grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir /
translated: The meaning of this is as follows: The author of the sutra intends to show that because there is no inference that proves the meaning of your assertion that things arise without a cause, and because there is the fault of being undermined by inference and the fault of being undermined by what is commonly acknowledged in this position of yours,üîΩthings do not arise without a cause.

original: yang dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med do zhes bya bar mdo mdzad pas dgongs so zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go //
analyzed: yang dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med do zhes bya bar mdo mdzad pas dgongs so zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go //
translated: This is what the author of the sutra intends to say.

original: gal te ji ltar rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod ce na /
analyzed: gal te ji ltar rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod ce na /
translated: If one says: ‚ÄúWhat is the fault of being undermined by inference?‚Äù

original: de bstan pa'i phyir /
analyzed: de bstan pa'i phyir /
translated: In order to demonstrate that, he says:

original: de la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod pa ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa smras so //
analyzed: de la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod pa ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa smras so //
translated: ‚ÄúThe fault of being undermined by inference‚Äù and so forth.

original: de la ji ltar rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa de bstan pa'i phyir /
analyzed: de la ji ltar rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa de bstan pa'i phyir /
translated: In order to demonstrate how there is the fault of being undermined by inference, he says:

original: kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med de /
analyzed: kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med de /
translated: ‚ÄúThings that are internal bases, which are accepted conventionally, do not arise without a cause,

original: spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir /
analyzed: spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir /
translated: because they possess generality and particularity,

original: dper na myu gu bzhin no zhes bya ba smras so //
analyzed: dper na myu gu bzhin no zhes bya ba smras so //
translated: like a sprout.‚Äù

original: de la kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams zhes bya ba 'di ni chos can @113a * //
analyzed: de la kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams zhes bya ba 'di ni chos can @113a * //
translated: Here, ‚Äúthings that are internal bases, which are accepted conventionally‚Äù is the subject.

original: yin la / rgyu med pa las skye ba med de zhes bya ba 'di ni bsgrub par bya ba chos yin /
analyzed: yin la / rgyu med pa las skye ba med de zhes bya ba 'di ni bsgrub par bya ba chos yin /
translated: ‚ÄúDo not arise without a cause‚Äù is the predicate to be proven.

original: spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba 'di ni sgrub pa'i chos yin /
analyzed: spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba 'di ni sgrub pa'i chos yin /
translated: The phrase ‚Äúbecause they possess generality and particularity‚Äù is the predicate of the probandum.

original: dper na myu gu bzhin no zhes bya ba 'di ni dpe yin par sbyar ro //
analyzed: dper na myu gu bzhin no zhes bya ba 'di ni dpe yin par sbyar ro //
translated: The phrase ‚Äúfor example, like a sprout‚Äù is the example.

original: de la kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams zhes bya ba ni dbu ma pas kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po mig la sogs pa gang dag yin pa rnams te /
analyzed: de la kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams zhes bya ba ni dbu ma pas kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po mig la sogs pa gang dag yin pa rnams te /
translated: The phrase ‚Äúthe things that are the internal bases of cognition that are accepted conventionally‚Äù refers to the things that are the internal bases of cognition, such as the eyes, that are accepted conventionally by the MƒÅdhyamika.

original: de rnams 'dir chos can du bya'o //
analyzed: de rnams 'dir chos can du bya'o //
translated: Those are the subjects here.

original: rgyu med pa las skye ba med de zhes bya ba ni kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po de rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med par bsgrub par bya ba ste /
analyzed: rgyu med pa las skye ba med de zhes bya ba ni kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po de rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med par bsgrub par bya ba ste /
translated: The phrase ‚Äúthey do not arise without a cause‚Äù is the probandum. The things that are the internal bases of cognition that are accepted conventionally do not arise without a cause.

original: de ni 'dir bsgrub par bya ba chos yin no //
analyzed: de ni 'dir bsgrub par bya ba chos yin no //
translated: That is the predicate of the probandum here.

original: spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba la spyi nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni mig la sogs pa skye mched drug po dag la skye mched ces bya ba spyi yod pa'i phyir ro //
analyzed: spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba la spyi nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni mig la sogs pa skye mched drug po dag la skye mched ces bya ba spyi yod pa'i phyir ro //
translated: Because it possesses generality, the six sense bases such as the eye are called sense bases, because the generality of sense bases exists.

original: khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni mig la sogs pa skye mched drug po dag la /
analyzed: khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni mig la sogs pa skye mched drug po dag la /
translated: Because it possesses particularity, the six sense bases such as the eye

original: mig dang / rna ba dang / sna dang / lce dang / lus dang / yid ces bya ba so so'i khyad par nyid yod pa'i phyir ro //
analyzed: mig dang / rna ba dang / sna dang / lce dang / lus dang / yid ces bya ba so so'i khyad par nyid yod pa'i phyir ro //
translated: are called the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind, because their individual particularities exist.

original: yang na spyi nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni skye mched thams cad la skye mched rnams skye mched rnams zhes bya ba spyi yod pa'i phyir ro //
analyzed: yang na spyi nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni skye mched thams cad la skye mched rnams skye mched rnams zhes bya ba spyi yod pa'i phyir ro //
translated: Alternatively, because it possesses generality, all sense bases are called sense bases, because the generality of sense bases exists.

original: khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni mi'i skye mched rnams zhes bya ba dang / lha'i skye mched rnams zhes bya ba dang / dud 'gro'i skye mched rnams zhes bya ba khyad par nyid yod pa'i phyir /üîΩnyid ces bya ba ni spyi dang khyad par gyi dngos po rnams ni spyi dang khyad par nyid do //
analyzed: khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni mi'i skye mched rnams zhes bya ba dang / lha'i skye mched rnams zhes bya ba dang / dud 'gro'i skye mched rnams zhes bya ba khyad par nyid yod pa'i phyir / nyid ces bya ba ni spyi dang khyad par gyi dngos po rnams ni spyi dang khyad par nyid do //
translated: The specific nature is the existence of the human sense spheres, the divine sense spheres, and the animal sense spheres.üîΩThe word ‚Äúnature‚Äù means the general and specific natures of things.

original: ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir te /
analyzed: ldan pa'i phyir zhes bya ba ni spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir te /
translated: Because of the existence of a specific nature means because of the existence of a general and specific nature.

original: de ni 'dir sgrub pa'i chos so //
analyzed: de ni 'dir sgrub pa'i chos so //
translated: This is the probandum here.

original: dper na myu gu bzhin no zhes bya ba ni 'di ltar myu gu la yang myu gu thams cad la myu gu zhes bya ba'i rigs spyi nyid kyang yod la /
analyzed: dper na myu gu bzhin no zhes bya ba ni 'di ltar myu gu la yang myu gu thams cad la myu gu zhes bya ba'i rigs spyi nyid kyang yod la /
translated: For example, like a sprout means just as a sprout has the general nature of a sprout, which is common to all sprouts,

original: 'bras kyi myu gu dang / nas kyi myu gu zhes bya ba la sogs pa khyad par nyid kyang yod pa ste /
analyzed: 'bras kyi myu gu dang / nas kyi myu gu zhes bya ba la sogs pa khyad par nyid kyang yod pa ste /
translated: and also has a specific nature, such as a rice sprout, a barley sprout, and so on.

original: dper na myu gu kun rdzob tu spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir rgyu med pa las skye ba med de /
analyzed: dper na myu gu kun rdzob tu spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir rgyu med pa las skye ba med de /
translated: For example, a sprout does not arise causelessly because it is a universal and a particular conventionally.

original: 'di ltar thog ma med pa'i rgyu brgyud pa las skye bas rgyu med pa @113b las skye ba med pa de bzhin du kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams kyang spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir rgyu med paüîΩlas skye ba med do //
analyzed: 'di ltar thog ma med pa'i rgyu brgyud pa las skye bas rgyu med pa @113b las skye ba med pa de bzhin du kun rdzob tu khas blangs pa nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams kyang spyi dang khyad par nyid dang ldan pa'i phyir rgyu med pa las skye ba med do //
translated: In the same way, things that are internal sense bases, which are accepted conventionally, do not arise causelessly because they are universals and particulars conventionally.

original: 'di ltar thog ma med pa'i rgyu brgyud pa las skye bas rgyu med pa las skye ba med de /
analyzed: 'di ltar thog ma med pa'i rgyu brgyud pa las skye bas rgyu med pa las skye ba med de /
translated: They do not arise causelessly because they arise from a beginningless continuum of causes.

original: de ni 'dir chos mthun pa'i dpe yin no //
analyzed: de ni 'dir chos mthun pa'i dpe yin no //
translated: This is a concordant example here.

original: de ltar re zhig khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa de la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med par dgongs so //
analyzed: de ltar re zhig khyod kyi rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa de la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med par dgongs so //
translated: Thus, since your proof of the arising of things from a cause is flawed because it is undermined by inference, it is intended that things do not arise causelessly.

original: gal te ji ltar grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod ce na /üîΩde bstan pa'i phyir grags pa'i gnod pa ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa smras so //
analyzed: gal te ji ltar grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod ce na / de bstan pa'i phyir grags pa'i gnod pa ni zhes bya ba la sogs pa smras so //
translated: If it is asked, ‚ÄúIs there a fault of contradiction with what is commonly acknowledged?‚ÄùüîΩTo demonstrate that, he says, ‚ÄúThe contradiction with what is commonly acknowledged,‚Äù and so on.

original: de la ji ltar grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pas de bstan pa'i phyir /
analyzed: de la ji ltar grags pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pas de bstan pa'i phyir /
translated: To demonstrate that there is a fault of contradiction with what is commonly acknowledged, he says,

original: 'jig rten 'di na yod pa gang yin pa de ni rgyu las skye bar grags pa ste /
analyzed: 'jig rten 'di na yod pa gang yin pa de ni rgyu las skye bar grags pa ste /
translated: ‚ÄúWhatever exists in this world is commonly acknowledged to arise from a cause.

original: dper na rgyu spun dag las snam bu dang rtsi rkyang dag las sab ma skye ba la sogs pa bzhin no zhes bya ba smras so //
analyzed: dper na rgyu spun dag las snam bu dang rtsi rkyang dag las sab ma skye ba la sogs pa bzhin no zhes bya ba smras so //
translated: For example, it is like a cloth arising from threads as its cause and a mat arising from reeds as its cause.‚Äù

original: 'di skad bstan te /
analyzed: 'di skad bstan te /
translated: This is what is being said.

original: ba lang rdzi'i chung ma yan chad la snam bu dang sab ma la sogs pa rgyu dang bcas pa las skye bar grags pas /
analyzed: ba lang rdzi'i chung ma yan chad la snam bu dang sab ma la sogs pa rgyu dang bcas pa las skye bar grags pas /
translated: From the wife of a cow herder on up, it is commonly acknowledged that a cloth, a mat, and so on arise from a cause.

original: khyod kyi kun rdzob tu nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa'i don de la ni grags pa dang 'gal ba'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med par dgongs
analyzed: khyod kyi kun rdzob tu nang gi skye mched kyi dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye bar sgrub pa'i don de la ni grags pa dang 'gal ba'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu med pa las skye ba med par dgongs
translated: In your proof that things arise without a cause, the subject, the internal sense bases, there is the fault of contradicting what is commonly accepted, and therefore things do not arise without a cause.

original: so // de ltar na re zhig rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ma yin pa las glo bur du skye ba med do //
analyzed: so // de ltar na re zhig rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ma yin pa las glo bur du skye ba med do //
translated: Thus, first, things do not arise from a nonthing that is a cause.

original: da ni rgyu med pa de dngos por gyur pa las skye pa dgag par bya ste /
analyzed: da ni rgyu med pa de dngos por gyur pa las skye pa dgag par bya ste /
translated: Now, we will refute arising from a nonthing that is a thing.

original: de'i phyir yang na rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu ngan ba ste /
analyzed: de'i phyir yang na rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu ngan ba ste /
translated: Therefore, ‚Äúarising without a cause‚Äù means arising from a bad cause.

original: chung ma med pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa bzhin no zhes bya ba smras te /
analyzed: chung ma med pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa bzhin no zhes bya ba smras te /
translated: It is like saying ‚Äúwithout a wife‚Äù and so on.

original: yang na rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu ngan pa ste /
analyzed: yang na rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu ngan pa ste /
translated: Or ‚Äúarising without a cause‚Äù means arising from a bad cause.

original: ngo bo nyid dang dbang phyug la sogs pa rgyur smra ba'i grub pa'i mtha' las mi mthun pa rgyur smra ba yin no zhes bya bar sbyar ro //
analyzed: ngo bo nyid dang dbang phyug la sogs pa rgyur smra ba'i grub pa'i mtha' las mi mthun pa rgyur smra ba yin no zhes bya bar sbyar ro //
translated: The meaning of the passage is that the non-Buddhist schools are not in agreement about the cause, some saying that the cause is intrinsic reality, some saying that the cause is God, and so on.

original: de la yang na zhes bya ba ni rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ma yin pa sngar bstan pa 'ba' zhig tu yang ma zad de /üîΩyang rnam pa gcig tu na rgyu med ces bya ba ni /
analyzed: de la yang na zhes bya ba ni rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ma yin pa sngar bstan pa 'ba' zhig tu yang ma zad de / yang rnam pa gcig tu na rgyu med ces bya ba ni /
translated: Moreover, the word ‚Äúor‚Äù in the root text is not meant to be exhaustive, for it is not only the case that things do not arise causelessly, as explained above.

original: rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ngan pa la yang bya'o zhes bya ba'i tha tshig @114a * //üîΩgo ; / rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu ngan pa ste zhes bya ba ni rgyu'i bya ba byed pa nyid ma yin pas rgyu med pa dang 'dra bar rgyu med pa zhes bya ste /
analyzed: rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ngan pa la yang bya'o zhes bya ba'i tha tshig @114a * // go ; / rgyu med ces bya ba ni rgyu ngan pa ste zhes bya ba ni rgyu'i bya ba byed pa nyid ma yin pas rgyu med pa dang 'dra bar rgyu med pa zhes bya ste /
translated: Moreover, the word ‚Äúor‚Äù is also meant to include the position that things arise from a bad cause.üîΩA bad cause is a cause that does not function as a cause, and so it is called a noncause.

original: gang ngo bo nyid kyis yod kyang skye bar byed pa ma yin pas ngan pa de ni rgyu med pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: gang ngo bo nyid kyis yod kyang skye bar byed pa ma yin pas ngan pa de ni rgyu med pa zhes bya'o //
translated: A bad cause is a cause that is intrinsically existent but does not function to give rise to an effect.

original: de yang ji lta bu zhe na /
analyzed: de yang ji lta bu zhe na /
translated: What is an example of a bad cause?

original: dper na chung ma med pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa bzhin no zhes bya ba smras te /üîΩdper na chung ma ngan pa skyon chags pa dngos por gyur pa yod kyang chung ma'i bya ba ni mi byed pas de la chung ma med pa zhes bya ba dang / bu ngan pa skyon chags pa dngos por gyur pa yod kyang bu'i bya ba mi byed pas de la bu med pa zhes bya ba bzhin du /
analyzed: dper na chung ma med pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa bzhin no zhes bya ba smras te / dper na chung ma ngan pa skyon chags pa dngos por gyur pa yod kyang chung ma'i bya ba ni mi byed pas de la chung ma med pa zhes bya ba dang / bu ngan pa skyon chags pa dngos por gyur pa yod kyang bu'i bya ba mi byed pas de la bu med pa zhes bya ba bzhin du /
translated: For example, it is like saying ‚Äúhe has no wife‚Äù and so on.üîΩFor example, even though a bad wife with faults exists, if she does not perform the duties of a wife, she is said to be no wife at all. Even though a bad son with faults exists, if he does not perform the duties of a son, he is said to be no son at all.

original: ngo bo nyid dang dbang phyug la sogs pa rgyur smra ba'i grub pa'i mtha' las mi mthun pa rgyur smra ba dag kyang rgyu ngan pa skyon chags pa dngos por gyur pa yod kyang rgyu'i bya ba mi byed pas de yang rgyu med pa zhes bya'o //
analyzed: ngo bo nyid dang dbang phyug la sogs pa rgyur smra ba'i grub pa'i mtha' las mi mthun pa rgyur smra ba dag kyang rgyu ngan pa skyon chags pa dngos por gyur pa yod kyang rgyu'i bya ba mi byed pas de yang rgyu med pa zhes bya'o //
translated: Likewise, even though a bad cause with faults exists, if it does not perform the function of a cause, it is said to be no cause at all.

original: rgyu ngan pa gang zhe na zhes bya ba ni rgyu med pa dngos po gyur pa yod kyang rgyu'i bya ba mi byed pas rgyu ngan pa theg pa zhes bya ba de yang gang zhe na zhes 'dir 'grel pa byed pa nyid kyis dri ba'i tshig yin no
analyzed: rgyu ngan pa gang zhe na zhes bya ba ni rgyu med pa dngos po gyur pa yod kyang rgyu'i bya ba mi byed pas rgyu ngan pa theg pa zhes bya ba de yang gang zhe na zhes 'dir 'grel pa byed pa nyid kyis dri ba'i tshig yin no
translated: Here, the author of the commentary himself asks the question: ‚ÄúWhat is a bad cause?

original: // de'i lan du 'grel pa byed pa nyid kyis /
analyzed: // de'i lan du 'grel pa byed pa nyid kyis /
translated: ‚Äù In response, the author of the commentary himself says:

original: ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug dang / skyes bu dang / gtso bo dang / dus dang / sred med kyi bu la sogs pa ste zhes bya ba smras te /
analyzed: ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug dang / skyes bu dang / gtso bo dang / dus dang / sred med kyi bu la sogs pa ste zhes bya ba smras te /
translated: ‚ÄúNature, ƒ™≈õvara, Puru·π£a, PradhƒÅna, Time, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, and so on.‚Äù

original: sogs pa zhes bya ba'i sgras ni tshangs pa dang / skye dgu'i bdag po dang / ma nu dang / gnam gyis bskos pa dang / par sig rnams kyi dru b'a na dang / bar bar rnams kyi yu na zhes bya ba'i bar dag bsdu'o //
analyzed: sogs pa zhes bya ba'i sgras ni tshangs pa dang / skye dgu'i bdag po dang / ma nu dang / gnam gyis bskos pa dang / par sig rnams kyi dru b'a na dang / bar bar rnams kyi yu na zhes bya ba'i bar dag bsdu'o //
translated: The word ‚Äúand so on‚Äù includes BrahmƒÅ, PrajƒÅpati, Manu, Dhat·πõ, and up to the Druvas of the Persians and the Yunas of the Barbaras.

original: ci'i phyir de dag rgyu med pa yin zhe na /
analyzed: ci'i phyir de dag rgyu med pa yin zhe na /
translated: Why are they causeless?

original: de'i phyir yang dag pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhes bya ba smras te /
analyzed: de'i phyir yang dag pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhes bya ba smras te /
translated: Therefore, he says, ‚Äúbecause they are not real.‚Äù

original: ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug dang / skyes bu dang / gtso bo dang / dus dang / sred med kyi bu dang / tshangs pa dang / skye dgu'i bdag po dang / ma nu dang / gnam gyi sa bskos pa dang / dru b'a na dang ;
analyzed: ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug dang / skyes bu dang / gtso bo dang / dus dang / sred med kyi bu dang / tshangs pa dang / skye dgu'i bdag po dang / ma nu dang / gnam gyi sa bskos pa dang / dru b'a na dang ;
translated: ƒ™≈õvara, puru·π£a, pradhƒÅna, time, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, BrahmƒÅ, PrajƒÅpati, Manu, Dak·π£a, and Dhatri,

original: yu na la sogs pa de dag ni ngo bo nyid kyi rgyu yang dag pa ma yin pa'i phyir te /
analyzed: yu na la sogs pa de dag ni ngo bo nyid kyi rgyu yang dag pa ma yin pa'i phyir te /
translated: are not the real causes of things, because

original: de dag ni kun rdzob tu dngos por gyur pa yin du zin kyang skyed par byed pa nyid ma yin pa'i phyir /
analyzed: de dag ni kun rdzob tu dngos por gyur pa yin du zin kyang skyed par byed pa nyid ma yin pa'i phyir /
translated: even though they are things in the conventional sense, they are not causes because they do not produce things.

analyzed: ngan pas med pa dang 'dra ba'i phyir rgyu nyid ma yin no //
translated: They are like non-causes, because they are non-causes.

original: da ni rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa de las skye @114b ba dgag par bya ste /
analyzed: da ni rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa de las skye @114b ba dgag par bya ste /
translated: Now, we will refute the arising of things from a non-cause.

analyzed: de'i phyir dngos po rnams rgyu med pa de las skye ba med de zhes bya ba la sogs pa smras so //
translated: Therefore, it is said, ‚ÄúThings do not arise from a non-cause.‚Äù

original: gal te dngos po rnams rgyu med pa de las ci'i phyir skye ba med ce na /
analyzed: gal te dngos po rnams rgyu med pa de las ci'i phyir skye ba med ce na /
translated: If things arise from a non-cause, why do they not arise from space?

original: de'i phyir de las skye bar ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i phyir yang ngo zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba smras so //
analyzed: de'i phyir de las skye bar ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i phyir yang ngo zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba smras so //
translated: Therefore, because there is no inference to prove that things arise from that, and because there is the fault of contradiction by inference, that is what is intended.

original: 'di skad bstan te /
analyzed: 'di skad bstan te /
translated: This is what is taught:

original: khyod kyi ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug la sogs pa de las dngos po rnams skye bar ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir /
analyzed: khyod kyi ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug la sogs pa de las dngos po rnams skye bar ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir /
translated: Because there is no inference to prove that things arise from your intrinsic reality, ƒ™≈õvara, and so on,

original: 'di ltar de ni tshig tsam du zad pas de'i phyir dngos po rnams rgyu ngan pa las skye ba med do //
analyzed: 'di ltar de ni tshig tsam du zad pas de'i phyir dngos po rnams rgyu ngan pa las skye ba med do //
translated: since that is mere words, therefore things do not arise from an inferior cause.

original: gzhan yang khyed kyi rgyu ngan pa ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug la sogs pa de las dngos po rnams skye bar sgrub pa de dag thams cad kho bos rjes su dpag pa dag gis dgag par nus pa'i gnod pa khyod la 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu ngan pa las skye ba med do
analyzed: gzhan yang khyed kyi rgyu ngan pa ngo bo nyid dang / dbang phyug la sogs pa de las dngos po rnams skye bar sgrub pa de dag thams cad kho bos rjes su dpag pa dag gis dgag par nus pa'i gnod pa khyod la 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu ngan pa las skye ba med do
translated: Moreover, because all of your proofs that things arise from that inferior cause, intrinsic reality, ƒ™≈õvara, and so on, can be refuted by our inferences, the fault of contradiction by inference arises for you, and therefore things do not arise from an inferior cause.

original: // yang ngo zhes bya ba'i sgra ni skyon gnyi ga bsdus pa'i don to zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba ni /
analyzed: // yang ngo zhes bya ba'i sgra ni skyon gnyi ga bsdus pa'i don to zhes bya bar dgongs so zhes bya ba ni /

original: de ltar khyod kyi rgyu ngan pa ngo bo nyid dang dbang phyug la sogs pa de las dngos po rnams skye bar ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / khyod kyi phyogs 'di la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu ngan pa las skye ba med do zhes bya bar mdo mdzad pas dgongs so zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go //
analyzed: de ltar khyod kyi rgyu ngan pa ngo bo nyid dang dbang phyug la sogs pa de las dngos po rnams skye bar ston pa'i rjes su dpag pa med pa'i phyir dang / khyod kyi phyogs 'di la rjes su dpag pa'i gnod par 'gyur ba'i phyir yang dngos po rnams rgyu ngan pa las skye ba med do zhes bya bar mdo mdzad pas dgongs so zhes bya ba'i tha tshig go //
translated: The meaning is that the Sutra master thinks, In this way, since there is no inference showing that things arise from a bad cause such as inherent nature or God, and since this position of yours is undermined by inference, things do not arise from a bad cause.

original: de ni re zhig rgyu med pas dngos por gyur pa las skye ba dgag pa spyir bstan pa yin no //
analyzed: de ni re zhig rgyu med pas dngos por gyur pa las skye ba dgag pa spyir bstan pa yin no //
translated: This is the general refutation of the arising of things from a non-thing cause.

original: da ni rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa las skye bar smra ba dag rim bzhin du dgag par bya'o //
analyzed: da ni rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa las skye bar smra ba dag rim bzhin du dgag par bya'o //
translated: Now, the proponents of arising from a non-thing cause should be refuted in order.

original: de la re zhig rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ngo bo nyid du smra ba dag gi grub pa'i mtha' ni gang yin /
analyzed: de la re zhig rgyu med pa dngos por gyur pa ngo bo nyid du smra ba dag gi grub pa'i mtha' ni gang yin /
